Comment: In my opinion, the reason for declining birthrates is less of a problem of 5k per birth but the individual standard of living one wishes to maintain vs the invidual standard one would want to have for their child.   Food, clothes, furniture, suitable housing, daycare, schools, college, hobbies, university etc.   All of this costs truckloads of money and that's just the factors that parents have to somehoe have I their control, not to mention wars inflation etc that is outside of their control.   Just think about it. All over the world parents usually want a better life for their kids, than the one that they lived themselves. This is a good trend for for "poorer" countries as an even 1% better life would consume in total less resources, than a 1% better life in a rich country. So with each generational increase in living standards the next generation of potential parents have it harder to reproduce this increase.    Right now we are experiencing a society that has reached the threshold for most people. Providing a better life seems no longer possible or so hard that people don't bother.  "Might as well just both work, drive a Mercedes and make expensive holiday trips all over the world."  As a society we have to find a way again to have a civil discourse to ask ourselves, where do we go with this?  Is perpetual growth possible?  Is a ok for a child to live a "lesser" life than its parents without experiencing any sort of stigmatization of either parties?  How do we support the people still willing to give life deposite all the current challenges?  How do we handle the ones that need assistance?  How do we treat the ones that fail?    But all I hear from whatever party is name calling and ideas like "let's throw out 5k dollar checks". This shut ain't gonna cut it. If it was that easy, people would have do e that decades ago.

Comment: The solution is obvious.  Cost of living has been on the incline since the beginning of the nation, but income has always lagged behind.  After WW2, there was a massive economic boom that petered out and died in the 1970â€™s.  Ever since then, despite the fact that workers are more productive than they ever have been, they are not being compensated for it.  We have a minimum wage system, but its only used by a minority of workers, yet workers above minimum are still undercompensated.  So tie minimum wage to productivity to set a floating wage that adjusts yearly, and have it adjusted further based on COLA which is already used for Social Security and eliminate inflation devaluation.    This rewards workers for performance and removes unscrupulous employers ability to underpay wages.  This would push bottom wages up to around 25/hr before local (state) adjustments.  There would be increases in prices, as people spend more money and thus raise demand, but it would not raise 1:1 to income.  By raising the floor you not only close the gap between productivity and wages, but also narrow the wealth gap.  We would need to adjust taxes by eliminating the payroll tax and adding a tiny tax, maybe a 1% federal VATS, to products, so it wouldnâ€™t destroy employers with small margins and the slight tax on all goods to compensate for that loss of tax revenues.

Comment: It's not just our country that is overpopulated.  It's the entire planet.  It took hundreds of thousands of years for the world population to grow to one billion.  Then, in another two hundred years or so, it jumped to the seven billion mark.  And only eleven years after that, in November 2022, it reachedÂ eight billion.Â   Environmental advocates attempting to slow global warming keep looking at green house gases, carbon footprints...  even cow farts.  But the only sure way to slow or even reverse global warming that I can see is to reduce the number of people living on it.  Every single one of those eight billion people living on this planet needs food, clothing, shelter, etc.  A high percentage of them have home heating/cooling, drive vehicles, work in office buildings, etc.  All of that food production/energy production/building materials generates heat, pollution and gases.  The easiest way to cut production of all of those negative societal byproducts is to reduce the need for them by reducing the earth's human population.  Maybe it's an unpopular opinion, but I see dropping birth rates as a good thing overall.

Comment: Lots of options. A good one to start with:  The cost of housing is stupid-high right now in many parts of the country. Housing is heavily influenced by supply/demand, and obviously you need housing to raise a family.  So... pass policies that deregulates the red tape and incentivizes building more housing. That gives people jobs, increases the supply of housing, lowers the cost of homes. Win/win/win.  ---  BUT, obviously easier said than done.  Everyone says they want more housing, but when that new housing development starts getting planned in *their* neighborhood suddenly they kick and scream about it. The *"Yes! Do that... but not in my backyard"* crowd shows up to the town zoning meeting and they manage to knock down the proposal. This is effectively California's problem in a nutshell and why it's so absurdly expensive to live there, but honestly some red states have the same problem.  Same sort of thing with nuclear power. People want it, it would reduce the cost of energy, but not in my backyard!  If we could ever get out of our own way... there is a lot we could do. And it wouldn't require us to pay people to have children.

Comment: I think the real solution to health care in this country is to decrease health insurance as much as possible and return to a system where doctors are actually paid directly by patients.  The fact that they can currently charge services that their patients don't actually (and often cannot) pay is kind of absurd. Hell, most doctors don't even KNOW what their services cost. That's handled by the (often incompetent... I'm speaking from experience) financial administrators.  If the pay was direct, prices would be forced to come down to a point where people could actually pay for them. Because doctors would not be able to operate if their patients couldn't afford their services. They'd go out of business.  Contrast (for comparison) with other health-related businesses where insurance is less ubiquitous: Chiropractic, Dentistry, Optometrists, Veterinarians. Most of those provide direct pricing scales (that are easily accessed) before service is rendered, and most can be afforded out of pocket. I'm not saying any of them are CHEAP, mind... but they're orders of magnitude cheaper than medical doctors. And I think it's mostly because they still deal directly (business-wise) with their customers.
